texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Shortened URLs make it easier to quickly reference complicated URLs and share them with other people. For example, https://url.major.io/reviews is definitely an easier method for sharing my  Fedora package review  list with other people instead of the full Bugzilla URL:
texts.text: Shortened URLs make it easier to quickly reference complicated URLs and share them with other people. For example, https://url.major.io/reviews is definitely an easier method for sharing my  Fedora package review  list with other people instead of the full Bugzilla URL:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/buglist.cgi?bug_status=__open__&component=Package%20Review&email1=mhayden%40redhat.com&emailreporter1=1&emailtype1=substring&list_id=12512813&product=Fedora&query_format=advanced
texts.text: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/buglist.cgi?bug_status=__open__&component=Package%20Review&email1=mhayden%40redhat.com&emailreporter1=1&emailtype1=substring&list_id=12512813&product=Fedora&query_format=advanced

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It also avoids those situations where you share a URL only to find that a chat system gobbled up special characters and your URL arrives broken on the other end.
texts.text: It also avoids those situations where you share a URL only to find that a chat system gobbled up special characters and your URL arrives broken on the other end.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, most URL shorteners depend on a web server and possibly a database server to serve up shortened URLs. This is a really quick setup that nearly any system administrator has done a hundred times or more, but what about the ongoing maintenance and updates? What about redundancy? How much will it cost?
texts.text: However, most URL shorteners depend on a web server and possibly a database server to serve up shortened URLs. This is a really quick setup that nearly any system administrator has done a hundred times or more, but what about the ongoing maintenance and updates? What about redundancy? How much will it cost?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That's simply too much work. I went on the hunt for an alternative.
texts.text: That's simply too much work. I went on the hunt for an alternative.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Shortening only with GitHub
texts.text: Shortening only with GitHub

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My first stop was nelsontky's  gh-pages-url-shortener . It uses GitHub issues to manage URLs, but the author mentions that the solution is a bit hacky. I need something more reliable.
texts.text: My first stop was nelsontky's  gh-pages-url-shortener . It uses GitHub issues to manage URLs, but the author mentions that the solution is a bit hacky. I need something more reliable.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Shortening with Cloudflare Pages' redirects
texts.text: Shortening with Cloudflare Pages' redirects

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Cloudflare offers  redirects  via a simple text file on its  Pages  service.  (This blog is hosted via Cloudflare pages and it's been extremely reliable and fast.)
texts.text: Cloudflare offers  redirects  via a simple text file on its  Pages  service.  (This blog is hosted via Cloudflare pages and it's been extremely reliable and fast.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The only downside is the limits applied to the redirects:
texts.text: The only downside is the limits applied to the redirects:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A project is limited to 100 total redirects. Each redirect declaration has a 1000-character limit. Malformed definitions are ignored. If there are multiple redirects for the same source path, the topmost redirect is applied.
texts.text: A project is limited to 100 total redirects. Each redirect declaration has a 1000-character limit. Malformed definitions are ignored. If there are multiple redirects for the same source path, the topmost redirect is applied.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you think you'll need less than 100 redirects and your destination URLs are under 1,000 characters, this might work for you. Head on over to  Deploying your site  and get going!
texts.text: If you think you'll need less than 100 redirects and your destination URLs are under 1,000 characters, this might work for you. Head on over to  Deploying your site  and get going!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What if you want (nearly) limitless redirects?
texts.text: What if you want (nearly) limitless redirects?

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Nearly limitless redirects with Cloudflare Workers
texts.text: Nearly limitless redirects with Cloudflare Workers

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: More Googling led to a blog post titled  World's Simplest URL Shortener using Cloudflare Workers . In the post,  Patrick Reader  lays out a simple javascript handler that takes the URI provided, compares it to a list of JSON keys, and then returns the destination URL.
texts.text: More Googling led to a blog post titled  World's Simplest URL Shortener using Cloudflare Workers . In the post,  Patrick Reader  lays out a simple javascript handler that takes the URI provided, compares it to a list of JSON keys, and then returns the destination URL.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: His instructions in the post get you up and running quickly. He also offers up a link to his own  GitHub repo  so you can fork it and get done quickly. The
texts.text: His instructions in the post get you up and running quickly. He also offers up a link to his own  GitHub repo  so you can fork it and get done quickly. The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: urls.json
texts.text: urls.json

texts.orig: file expects the keys to be short URIs and the values to be the long URLs, like this:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Manual work is not my thing, so I wanted to get GitHub Actions to do the work for me when I changed my list of short URLs. For that, I first needed an API key from Cloudflare. For that, go to your  API Tokens  page at Cloudflare and do these steps:
texts.text: Manual work is not my thing, so I wanted to get GitHub Actions to do the work for me when I changed my list of short URLs. For that, I first needed an API key from Cloudflare. For that, go to your  API Tokens  page at Cloudflare and do these steps:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All that's left is to drop in a GitHub Actions workflow to make it all automated. You can copy the  workflow file  from  my repository :
texts.text: All that's left is to drop in a GitHub Actions workflow to make it all automated. You can copy the  workflow file  from  my repository :

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
name: Deploy

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    name: Deploy
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Publish
        uses: cloudflare/wrangler-action@1.3.0
        with:
          apiToken: ${{ secrets.CF_API_TOKEN }}
texts.text:
name: Deploy

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    name: Deploy
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Publish
        uses: cloudflare/wrangler-action@1.3.0
        with:
          apiToken: ${{ secrets.CF_API_TOKEN }}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Each time you change a URL in
texts.text: Each time you change a URL in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: urls.json
texts.text: urls.json

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , GitHub Actions assembles your application for Cloudflare Workers and ships it to Cloudflare. You can edit your URLs right in the GitHub web editor, save them, and they'll be active in a minute or two!
texts.text: , GitHub Actions assembles your application for Cloudflare Workers and ships it to Cloudflare. You can edit your URLs right in the GitHub web editor, save them, and they'll be active in a minute or two!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Enjoy! 🎉
texts.text: Enjoy! 🎉
